HolmesM10
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
25.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 12 janvier 2014
One of my favorite indie games

A grind based dungeon crawler, aparently based on some old school games ive never played, but if they are anywhere near as good as legend of grimrock ive missed out

Within the game you control a party of 4 characters at the same time and move in first person through square grind based dungeons, the game has a great degree of micromanagement, you use the different attacks of your party members individually, they suffer from different status effects, they all have their own stats and they all suffer from hunger and carrying limitations, not to mention since your characters are set up in a square formation within the square grind you are on attacks from different directions affect different party members, learning to balance all of this is pivotal to success

the dungeons in this game are all well designed with clever puzzles and some nice settings. The combat in the game is for the most part decent, it can get a little boring agaisnt single enemies, since running around em is usually enough, but when multiple enemies are present it becomes really challenging, since you must maneuver the environment skillfully to avoid getting trapped and having your weakest party members killed. Your party members can belong to 4 races and 3 different classes, each with their own characteristics, the mage class is a standout, offering the most interesting and challenging combat of all classes. The game in general is very hard but fair, with only a couple of traps and situations id describe as cheap

When it comes to graphics, they are somewhat simple but pleasing to the eye, with an adequate amount of detail on screen and a good art direction, its understandably claustrophobic but this goes well with the game's setting and mechanics, i guess one flaw on this regard is the fact we are dealing with the overly familiar middle ages fantasy setting here

the game has a very long campaign, it took me around 19 hours to finish the main campaign and i didnt even find all the secrets, you can start a new game with different party configurations and the game has steam workshop support with over 700 custom dungeons, this thing has some serious replay value

fantastic game overall, my mayor complain is the fact a game like this begs for randomization and yet it has none, it could really benefit for random dungeons with random loot, random spells, random enemies in random locations, but well i guess the game couldnt have these brilliant puzzles otherwise, and the steam workshop support does alleviate this shortcoming a bit﻿
 
Nuclear Kangaroo
1,298 produits enregistrés
1
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
44.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 29 novembre 2015
LoG is a grid style dungeon crawler that has revived the genre from its dying lineage from such games like 80's Dungeon Master. This 13 floor, heavy puzzled, medium combat gameplay title does an excellent job at presenting new comers and old to the maze like dungeon of the Mountain of Grimrock. Most of the puzzles work around pushing lose stones that protrude out from the walls and the combat style is of dancing around in a grid motion around the enemy. There is no tank and spank strategy here unless playing on easy difficulty.

The game will take 20+ hours to complete depending on whether or not you spend the time to do the puzzles and/or find all the missing treasures that can be used for achievements or just upgrading you characters with better equipment. The graphics are well done and the animation is quite well too. There is an unlockable character that you must find in the dungeon which will let you run a new game once found with all new traits that will be different compared to the games regular 4 person party you've played with. If enjoyed this alone is great replay value that extends the life even further to this gem.

Looking for a great grid style dungeon crawler look no further to The Legend of Grimrock!
 
mr. nails

Found myself in a dungeon with crappy weapons and gear. Murdered a few critters and ate them. Found better gear, murdered some snails, delicious. Got more gear made my way to the exit, but angry critters blocked my way. Danced, killed, and twerked my way past the critters and made my escape. I win.

You can win too if you buy this game.

9 / 10
 
jgaltx
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
23.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 28 décembre 2013
This is a first-person RPG in the style of Eye of the Beholder. The plot is simple but appropriately so. You are four convicts who have been exiled to Mount Grimrock. You receive a pardon upon being exiled because nobody makes it down and out of the mountain. Ever. This game is an epic dungeon crawl and it knows it. You need to find light sources or you will die. You need to find food or you will die. You need to manage your inventory and weight loads or, yes, you will die. The game is pretty tough on the normal difficulty and you can ramp it up with a hard mode as well as an old-school mode where you must create your own maps out-of-game. The itemization, art direction, and music all contribute to an ambiance that other games from top-tier studios would be wise to emulate. It is not without its flaws. The combat system is rather clunky and the grid-layout of the game allows many enenmies killed through mechanical exploitation. The real difficulty is in the carefully crafted puzzles that push the limitations of the grid-based system to new levels of awesome and often require precision movement and perfect timing. This game goes on sale often but it is worth it at full price.
 
ephemeral
0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
1
Recommandé
13.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 19 juin 2022
Very few games manage to capture the magic of a basement round of Dungeons & Dragons--but there's something even more special that I think only Legends of Grimrock has ever tried to explore: anybody who spent much time as a kid poring over a Monster Manual or a DM's Guide knows that special feeling you get between sessions where you want to play D&D but have nobody to play with, of having to imagine your party and the whole adventure you wish you were having. Dungeon-crawling in Grimrock is like bringing those lonely (but uniquely amazing, if only because they were all yours!) adventures to life and putting them on-screen.
 
Yossarian
0
4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0

This is the best crawler I have played in a long time. the controls are responsive, puzzles are made well, secrets are a challenge to find. Overall a well made game and very fun to play. if you enjoy old school crawlers then you will like LoG. After I do my hard/oldschool run im starting the second LoG and hope its just as good or better. Enjoy.

4,492 produits enregistrés
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
44.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 1 juillet 2016
I picked up this game because when i was a kid, two games had me glued to the screen: Dungeon Master and Arcana (Genesis). Both of them remind me a lot of this one. I dare even to say most elements on this game looks like completely inspired from Dungeon Master.

This "genre" seemed quite dead for me, and i thought it was because people got bored of crawling tile by tile in a dungeon. Thank you, Almost Human for reviving this amazing genre.

Now about the game: The lore is about a very tall mountain called Grimrock which has a Man-made dungeon inside, But no one have managed so far to venture out of there. In fact, as the game's manual explain, in ONE of the expeditions, ONE of the lesser knights of a group survived, and he reported a lot of bizare creatures and visions, only to actually die in his bed on the next day.

Then since no knight in the kingdom want to risk their lives, the King made a new rule: From time to time, he would gather 4 of the most brave PRISIONERS, that's right, and fly them on an airship and throw them in there by the top.

The moment they were thrown in there, they were completely forgiven of all crimes. All they had to do was to survive until the bottom.

And these are the guys you play with! Which can be customized: 4 different races, 3 classes, each one having at least over 6 different specializations.

The enemies are not Turn based battling either. They also move under the rules of 1 tile per time but they can freely attack you once you're on a tile they can reach either with melee or ranged attacks. The same applies to you, so be swift and even DANCE around with the enemy if you need to. Cunning and Dexterity are sometimes the key of survival. But dont get discouraged, you'll learn the hang of it after some time.

Oh, and a note about spiders: Yes there are spiders in this game and YES they are quite scary even for those without arachnophobia. So if you HAVE arachnophobia, i recommend playing under this mod:
No Spider Mod 
Un article du Workshop pour Legend of Grimrock
Par : Freebird
This mod is for all you guys out there who suffer from arachnophobia like I do. I just couldn't play this nice little game because of all these disgusting crawlers in it.


It replaces every spider for another enemy in the game (which sometimes can make it even harder) and removes all spider eggs completely. So no excuses for not playing anymore!

The puzzles are everywhere as well. Some are VERY well hidden. i recomend inspecting EVERY wall you can. some hide BUTTONS or HINTS about secrets nearby. if you find anything unusual about a wall, get face-to-face with it and use the mouse to click STUFF on it.

Overall, the game managed to go back a few years in RPG and made me so happy. I not only recommend it, but i'm now excited to see what else the team can make besides this series.
 
Felixinius
0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile

Recommandé
62.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 21 novembre 2014
Absolut Spitzenmässig :-)

jeder der frühere Dungeon Crawler wie Dungeon Master, Eye of the Beholder oder Ishar usw mochte, wird Legend of Grimrock lieben.

Die Designer haben das klassische Old School Spielprinzip in ein neues Gewand gesteckt.
Die freie 3D sicht bei gedrückter rechter Maustaste finde ich eine sehr schöne Idee, auch wenn sie nicht wirklich einen sehr grossen spielerischen Nutzen hat, sorgt die 180 grad freie Sicht auf dem Feld auf dem man gerade steht für einen netten Atmosphärischen Bonus.

Habe vor wenigen Minuten den ersten Teil durchgespielt.
Dieser spielt ausnamslos im inneren eines Berges, jetzt habe ich richtig Lust auf den zweiten Teil.
Vorallem freue ich mich auf die neuen Aussenbereiche !!

Zum Abschluss noch ein Lob an die Designer , weiter so und mehr davon !!

 
Karemon

0
Non recommandé
23.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 19 décembre 2017
There's plenty of fun to be had in Grimrock, but as a whole package, the game will be too frustrating for anyone to reasonably complete without a walkthrough. The puzzles start fun and satisfying, but quickly ramp up to ridiculously hard, and then just plain ridiculous. I put down my game when I looked up the solution to a specific puzzle:

There was a room with 4 empty shelves with nonsensical riddles next to each. The correct solution is to put four obscure items on the shelves, and even after seeing the solution online I couldn't see any relation between the riddles and the items the shelves required. Worst of all, some of these obscure items were only seen several hours ago in your gameplay, requiring you to do a ridiculous amount of backtracking to one of the first areas. Since inventory space is limited, you're likely to have thrown out these seemingly useless items. THIS IS NOT A PUZZLE. This is just badly designed and tedious.
 
Hot Gamer Girlfriend
225 produits enregistrés
1

6 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
0.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 24 décembre 2015
Итак, Legend of Grimrock:

Сразу попрошу не обращать внимания на количество наигранных часов - жуткую массу времени награл в нее на iPad, на разных уровнях сложности, с различными комбинациями персонажей.

Четверых зэков бросают в Гримрок - скалу-тюрягу, из которой еще никому не удавалось выбраться. Единственный известный вход в нее - через яму на вершине, а забраться на вершину можно только с помощью цеппелина. И даже целые экспедиции, отправлявшиеся туда за славой и экспой, сгинули бесследно. Звучит жутковато, не правда ли? Но не для наших героев, впавших в подобную немилость за детские шалости: они отжимали у школяров их аккаунты в Стиме, отбирали у них отложенные на школьных завтраках деньги, чтобы купить себе CS: GO и покрасить Зевсу бороду зеленым в Dota 2. Так вот, ходят слухи, что если с вершины горы спускаться вниз, через заброшенные катакомбы, то можно будет выйти к подножию горы, нащупать выход, улизнуть от правосудия и дальше заниматься различными непотребствами.

На выбор предоставлено четыре героя. Можно выбрать и настроить их самому, а можно положиться на случай и начать рандомной партией. Выбирать можно из четырех рас, особенности, в общем и целом, классические: 1) Минотавры сильны, брутальны, но туповаты и неуклюжи, а также жрут в два горла; 2) Ящерики ловки и незаметны - воткнуть перо в бочину зазевавшемуся дохлому легионеру или шмальнуть из арбалета в мирно ползущую по своим делам гигантскую кровожадную улитку - лучший выбор; 3) Пучеглазые инсектоиды - не самые лучшие бойцы, но с магией дружат лучше других ребят. Рожей, конечно, не вышли, но зато их файерболлы самые горячие на всем Диком Западе. Жрут, кстати, меньше других; 4) И, наконец, людишки - самая универсальная раса. Могут и колдовать, и черепушку разбить кому-нибудь, и красться незаметно. В общем, лепите кого угодно, все у человеков в руках спорится. Можно выбрать тян ;)

Вариантов прокачки и группировки разных героев тьма, что дает задел на множество перепрохождений, если вам не надоест одна и та же карта из раза в раз.

Ладно, это уже начинает смахивать на руководство, так что перейду к сути: финская контора Almost Human очень здорово играет на струнах ностальгии всех благородных донов, кто в лихие девяностые лазил по подземельям Dungeon Master, Eye of the Beholder, Lands of Lore. Сколько времени автор этих строк убил на вышеперечисленные тайтлы - не поддается счету. В общем, данным товарищам можно садиться за игру, и чуть ли не сразу на харде погрузиться в атмосферу мрака, отчаяния и безысходности :) Всем остальным, возможно, потребуется вникнуть. Геймплей прост и сложен одновременно: проходим этаж за этажом вниз, по пути выкашиваем орды всякой нечисти, разгадываем загадки (не всегда стройные и логичные, к сожалению). Если не обращаться к прохождениям, то на одних поисках скрытых кнопок и комнат можно убить время, за которое нормальные люди заработают денег на домик в подмосковье. Для совсем хардкорных можно полоностью отключить игровую прорисовку карты, а вместо этого взять карандаш в зубы, тетрадку в клеточку (как в старые добрые), и самому рисовать карты клетку за клеткой.
Предлагаю перейти к итогам.

Достоинства:
+ Классический геймплей, вобравший в себя многие хорошие черты прародителей жанра;
+ Вариативность расово-национального состава, со своими особенностями;
+ Хорошая ролевая система, прокачка разнообразна и весьма сбаланисрована;
+ Хардкор-режим с карандашом и тетрадкой - особые впечатления гарантированны;
+ Приятный движок, хоть и неоправданно прожорливый, как по мне;
+ Возможность перепройти игру за предыдущего зэка.

Недостатки:
- Сюжет хоть и подается неплохо, но довольно-таки банален и однообразен;
- Для пущего хардкору можно было бы сделать опцию с рандомными подземельями. Хотелось бы хорошего респавна монстров. Хотя бы на высоких уровнях;
- Нет наземных локаций (во второй части сделали-таки);
- Этот минус отчасти вытекает из предыдущего: Бедноватый геймдизайн, к концу уже просто надоедают одинаковые стены.


Кому я порекомендую данную игру:
1) Однозначно брать старым пердунам типа меня, скучающим по DM, EoB, LoL. Скупая ностальгическая слеза практически обеспечена;
2) Любителям хороших классических ролевок в целом, тоже может приглянуться.
3) Почитателям рогаликов.

Кому не стоит ее брать:
1) Любителям активных игр;
2) Если ваши интересы ограничиваются CS: GO, Dota 2 или (ужс какой!) Saints Raw.
3) Всем нелюбителям РПГ, а особенно классической их части.

Общий вердикт: 7.8 подземелий из 10.
 
Alt.A1R
553 produits enregistrés
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
78.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 19 mars 2014
Legend of Grimrock est un petit bijou pour peu qu'on adhère au concept un peu old school.

Vous incarnez un groupe de prisonniers de la prison de Grimrock, et votre but est de vous en échapper, chaque étage représentant un niveau de jeu.

Un très bon Level Design, un côté RPG poussé (gestion de persos et craft),
lancement des sorts original et RP, des énigmes très bien pensées (cela faisait longtemps que je n'étais pas resté bloqué aussi longtemps sur des énigmes dans un jeu),
une difficulté bien dosée, une ambiance sombre excellente et des graphismes soignés.
La durée de vie est très acceptable et le jeu comporte son lot de secrets .

Quasiment aucuns défauts en vue, peut être la quantité de nourriture trop abondante à mon gout, ce qui casse le côté "survie" initialement recherché ainsi que l’absence d'un mode de difficulté très élevé pour ceux les personnes rodées au jeu qui recherche un challenge à leur mesure.
Sinon l'IA des ennemis est un peu limite une fois que l'on a compris son fonctionnement, ce qui permet au joueur de tourner facilement autour des monstres pour les frapper puis partir en retraite pour mieux revenir attaquer sournoisement par la suite sans que l'adversaire n'ait le temps de réagir( tout ceci si l'environnement le permet bien-sur).
Il manque aussi une traduction française :(

en bref ce jeu fait quasiment un perfect!


* Points forts :

+ C'est plutôt joli
+ L'ambiance un peu claustrophobe, un peu survie
+ La personnalisation, les fiches de personnages
+ Combats fun
+ Level design de qualité
+ Les énigmes


* Points faibles :

- IA des ennemis limite
- Un peu trop facile
- Un peu trop de provisions
- Pas de traduction française


17/20
 
SenSx

Non recommandé
16.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 11 mars 2016
I am not sure why this game has received the critical acclaim it did, because aside from bringing back the long-dead (at the time) genre of tile-based dungeon crawling, the design, mechanics and gameplay are somewhat mediocre.

It is effectively a point-and-click puzzler with combat - however, the creativity of puzzles is hurt by the game's limited mechanics, and the combat is shallow and a huge chore. Legend of Grimrock would please neither fans of adventure games nor fans of dungeon crawlers, unless they are desperate for anything in the genre.
 
Solipso
441 produits enregistrés
1
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile

Recommandé
18.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 4 décembre 2014
Je crois que mon dernier dungeon crawler était Shining in the holy ark sur Saturn et il était géant! Et après avoir touché de ce Legend of Grimrock, je suis pris d'envie d'en refaire d'autres classiques toujours dans le même genre (et un Etrian Odyssey en plus frais). Bref, ce jeu est un hommage à un genre quasi disparu ces dernières années (pour ne pas dire décennies) et il rend magnifiquement hommage.
Malheureusement, on se retrouve avec les mêmes horreurs qu'à l'époque des Dungeon Master et autres Eye of the Beholder, il est sacrément trop dur :'( J'ai beau avoir mis la difficulté moyenne et j'ai souffert tellement qu'il a eu raison de ma motivation (ou alors je suis trop mauvais). Je n'ai même plus le courage de le finir ... j'aurai dû choisir "easy for noob player" T_T

Recommandé
63.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 26 décembre 2015
Das Spiel hat speziell für mich alles richtig gemacht: Zum einen ist es eine Dungeon Master-Adaption, ja fast schon ein Remake zu einem der großartigsten Spiele, das die Entwicklerstudios je zur Welt gebracht haben. Das allein hätte schon für eine positive Bewertung gereicht, denn in dieser Beziehung bin ich einfach ein hoffnungsloser Fanboy.

Hinzu kommt aber, dass Almost Human im Detail so gut wie alles richtig gemacht hat: Das Spiel sieht großartig aus, steuert sich exzellent, bietet knackige Rätsel, eine tolle Monstervielfalt und dünstet somit unterm Strich aus jeder Pore den puren Dungeon Crawler-Geist aus. Wer es hardcore mag, darf Karopapier zur Hand nehmen – allen anderen lassen die Entwickler sogar die Wahl einer Automap. Wenn man dieses (sehr spezielle) Genre liebt, muss man einfach zugeben: Viel besser hätten die Finnen nicht arbeiten können.

Évaluation publiée le 13 novembre 2014
This is a RPG dungeon crawling game that I found to be very enjoyable, good dungeon design in general. Also the puzzles are top notch and varied. The reason I stopped playing this though is I needed to place certain items in the walls at certain areas and I left the right ones somewhere else because I wasn't going to use them. Because of this reason I would horde items. You shouldn't get bored with this game when you play it.

P.S. Keep an eye out for those secrets.

Recommandé
25.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 8 mai 2014
Un juego muy interesante, yo me he divertido bastante.
Rememora los juegos de rol de la vieja escuela en los que tenías que hacerte tú mismo el mapa de la mazmorra para no perderte.
Las trampas y los puzzles están muy bien pensados aunque ♥♥♥ niguno tienes problemas verdaderos para resolverlos.
Tiene muchas zonas secretas, que se te pasan si no vas ♥♥♥ sumo cuidado, ♥♥♥ interesantes objetos.
La versatilidad de los personajes no es muy grande y no tiene ningún tipo de aleatoriedad a la hora de rejugarlo, siempre te vas a encontrar lo mismo en el mismo sitio.
El gran desafío reside en pasarse el juego ♥♥♥ el personaje desbloqueable, el final es hilarante, la historia te sumerge en un suspense continuo, pero promete más de lo que acaba sucediendo al final.

En general un juego fresco, más interesante que Etrian Odyssey y mucho menos pesado que éste. La opción de crear tus propias mazmorras o jugar las de otras personas lo hace muy interesante.
 
MooNRaN

Recommandé
317.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 4 juillet 2014
¿Cual es la diferencia entre este RPG y la gran mayoría que aparecen actualmente en el mercado? pues que este juego es como aquellos de hace 15 o 20 años. La gente ♥♥♥ cierta edad recordará los Eye of the Beholder, Lands of Lore y demás juegos de aquel estilo, pues este Legend of Grimrock es todo un homenaje a aquel tipo de juegos. No es solo matar bichos, también es resolver puzzles, encontrar secretos y averiguar que se esconde en el fondo del monte grimrock. Y todo moviéndose casilla a casilla, como en aquellas épocas. Es volver un par de décadas atrás en el tiempo, volver a los orígenes de los RPG. Y cuando te lo acabas tienes una ingente colección de dungeons hechos por la gente gracias al excelente editor que trae consigo... o puedes hacer tu propio dungeon si quieres poner a prueba al resto de jugadores!!. Gracias a este juego muchos otros juegos del mismo estilo han aparecido y muchos de ellos son excelentes títulos...¡¡¡larga vida al Legend of Grimrock!!!

Recommandé
3.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 25 juin 2022
Really well made and creative puzzles, where texts and shenanigans are employed to solve it;
Traps are both deadly and fun, where you can use them in your favor;
Magic spells are cast by correctly combining symbols (which you learn from scrolls) and then clicking to cast. This makes if balanced as you must think fast, plan ahead or you may lose a party member (you must control 3 while also casting the spell) if you take too long or even miss the right symbols (you could accidentally cast a poison spell in the wrong place and be wiped);
The skill evolution, potion crafting and party management are really nice as well, giving a full of importance for the item handling.
Also, it's dungeon crawler RPG. Many people seem to hate this genre, but i really love it after years of playing Shin Megami Tensei, thus it's nice to see a first person dungeon crawler.
 
Agalliarept
0
9 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
30.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 30 juin 2014
Ich habe vorher noch nie einen Dungeon Crawler gespielt und ich denke Legend of Grimrock war eine gute erste Wahl.

Für Unerfahrene, wie mich, war der Einstieg sehr leicht zu bewältigen. Sehr einfache Rätsel zu Beginn, die Optik ist sehr liebevoll gestaltet und schon war die Motiviation da, sich weiter durch den Dugeon zu prügeln. Die Entwickler haben Geschick bei der Levelgestaltung bewiesen und so gibt es bis zum Ende jede Menge Neues zu Entdecken und es kommt bis zum Schluss keine Langeweile auf, daher hab ich das Spiel auch gesuchtet :-D.

Meiner Meinung nach sollte das Spiel jedoch auch für erfahrene "Crawler" eine tolle Erfahrung sein, da es einen Oldschool-Modus gibt, in dem es keine Karte gibt und man sich selber eine ganz altmodisch auf Papier anfertigen muss. Außerdem gibt es massig Möglichkeiten zur Entwicklung seines vierköpfigen Heldengespanns gibt. So hat jeder der Helden mehrere Skill-Ausprägungen. Der Magier kann sich klassisch auf ein Element konzentrieren oder eine Mischung aus mehreren wählen, während der Fernkämpfer/Dieb sich eben auf Wurfgeschosse, Pfeil und Bogen, oder Nahkampf "Assassinen-Skills" spezialisieren kann und der Kämpfer wählt seinen Waffentyp der Wahl.

Langzeitmotivation ist dadurch gegeben, dass die Skillpoints nur wenige pro Levelaufstieg sind und man deswegen nur schwer überhaupt eine Skill-Spezialisierung komplett abschließen kann. Es ist auch nicht nötig um das Spiel zu beenden, jedoch muss man sich daher schon früh für eine Richtung entscheiden. So bleiben jede Menge Ausprägungen ungenutzt, die Im nächsten Durchlauf darauf warten, getestet zu werden.
Der Dungeon bleibt natürlich der Selbe, was natürlich wiederum einen 2. Durchlauf etwas uninteressanter macht. Dabei sollte jedoch noch der Steam-Workshop erwähnt werden, in dem ich jede menge Eigenkreationen von Spielern gesehen habe, die darauf warten durchgespielt zu werden. Da kann man natürlich nichts über die Qualität dieser Dungeons sagen ;-).

Mein Fazit: Ein tolles Spiel und für unerfahrener Crawler ist das Preis/Leistungs Verhältnis top! Ich habe über 20 Stunden für das durchspielen gebraucht. Erfahrene werden wahrscheinlich einige Stunden weniger brauchen, jedoch lohnt es sich dank schöner Grafik und intelligentem Leveldesign auch für solche unter Euch. Für reine Actionfans ist das Spiel jedoch nichts, da die Rätsel einfach 50% des Spiels ausmachen.

Ein kleiner Tipp zum Schluss: Nutzt die Möglichkeit eure Helden selber zu wählen, da es noch 2 Rassen gibt, die in der Vorauswahl garnicht vorkommen und man sich so von Anfang an schon eine Taktik für seine Party überlegen und aktiv beeinflussen kann.
 
Tovu
0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
22.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 22 décembre 2018
Jakoś nigdy specjalnie nie przepadałem za dungeon crawlerami. Nie czułem magii tych tytułów. Aż nadszedł czas na Legend of Grimrock. Parafrazując klasyka: Na początku był chaos, a z chaosu wyłonił się… Grimrock. Skromne RPG, które świata nie zawojowało, a naprawdę szkoda, bo tradycja „tunelowego” RPG sięga zamierzchłych czasów w rozwoju gier w ogóle. Największy ich rozkwit przypadł na lata 80 i 90, gdzie królowały takie serie ja Might and Magic, Wizardry, The Bard’s Tale czy Eye of the Beholder i z pewnością większość starszych graczy wspomniane tytuły kojarzy.

Historia jest prosta jak drut, ale nie ona stanowi o miodności tej gry, choć oczywiście trzeba wspomnieć o co tutaj chodzi. Cała nasza drużyna zostaje skazana za jakieś przestępstwa i zrzucona w czeluści tytułowej góry. Owa placówka jest raczej miejscem z którego się nie wychodzi żywym, więc jak łatwo się domyślić naszym głównym celem będzie wyswobodzenie z przeklętego miejsca pozostając przy życiu. Przyjdzie nam przedzierać się przez więzienne lochy na kilkunastu poziomach. Wystój wnętrz jest kapitalny, choć poszczególne poziomy diametralnie się między sobą teksturami nie różnią. To labirynt w którym bardzo łatwo się zgubić. Nieraz będzie koniecznym powrócić także naraz w już zwiedzane poziomy, bo coś ominęliśmy lub dostaliśmy dostęp tam gdzie wcześniej nie dało rady się przebić. Niemal czuć brud ścian. Te początkowe są brudne, zniszczone zębem czasu, porośnięte mchem. Jedyne światło dają zawieszone tu i ówdzie na ścianach pochodnie. Klimat jest kapitalny. Grajcie w słuchawkach, najlepiej po zmierzchu. Dźwięk robi tu swoje. Odgłosy z oddali, woda skapująca z sufitu lub też zupełna cisza wpływają na odczucie odosobnienia, czasami wręcz klaustrofobii. Dzięki temu wczuciu gra była dla mnie niezwykłym doświadczeniem. Ale, ale… Zapomniałem o jednym. Sławetnym zdaniem: Przed wyruszeniem dalej, należy zebrać drużynę.

Możemy stworzyć sobie maksymalnie cztery postacie i warto to zrobić. Dobieranie statystyk i ras sprawiło, że jedną godzinę spędziłem na doborze optymalnej grupki. Ras jest tylko kilka do wyboru, przy czym mają też unikatowe zdolności. Ja w moim teamie miałem na przodzie Minotaura barbarzyńcę, ludzkiego wojownika oraz insektoidalnego złodziejaszka i jaszczurzego czarodzieja, ustawionymi za ich plecami. Uwielbiam zabawy z magią, więc jakie było moje zaskoczenie przy systemie czarowania. Aby rzucić jakikolwiek czar to trzeba poznać kombinację run(znaleźć właściwy zwój), mieć odpowiedni poziom doświadczenia, wykupić go na drzewku rozwoju i za każdym razem wcisnąć runy w danej kolejności. Na piśmie sprawia wrażenia przewlekłego, ale w trakcie gry daje frajdę, tym bardziej, że przedmiotów jest tutaj jak na lekarstwo. Z racji ograniczonej liczby punktów doświadczenia trzeba specjalizować się tylko w kilku rzeczach. Przy Magu było to o tyle irytujące, bo może się nauczyć czarów z czterech szkół: Ziemia, Ogień, Woda, Powietrze, a to połowa z ścieżek jakich może się uczyć. Uderzenie bronią też wymaga wciśnięcia odpowiedniego klawisza lub ikony broni pod portretem postaci. Walka była dla mnie zarówno prosta jak i łatwa. Pojedynczego wroga należy wywabić w miejsce gdzie można z łatwością z nim gonić się tak, że w momencie przejścia z pola na pole zadać mu obrażenia i odskoczyć na bok, jednocześnie samemu ich nie odnosząc. Wystarczą do tego cztery pola. Sytuacja się zmienia, gdy potem zagęszczenie przeciwników rośnie, a manewrowanie między nimi stanowi większe wyzwanie i sprowadza się do tego, aby nie dać się zagonić w róg. Każdorazowe znalezienie jakiegoś oręża czy zwoju naprawdę dawało mi frajdę, bowiem nie ma tu zatrzęsienia żelastwem jak w elder scrolls czy gothicu. Części ubioru, oręż, eliksiry bo też tutaj występując są cenne.

Alchemia też jest fajna, bowiem tu i ówdzie znajdujemy rośliny, które można wprawdzie zjeść, ale w kombinacji w innymi chwastami i znalezionymi recepturami możemy stworzyć, w znalezionej zaraz na początku aparaturze, eliksiry życia czy many, ale żeby nie było za łatwo twórcy wprowadzili ograniczenia co udźwigu danej postaci. Minotaur podniesie więcej, niż człowiek. Zje też nieco więcej, bo w grze widnieje pasek głodu, przez co raz na jakiś czas trzeba się pożywić, ale na szczęście z jedzeniem nie jest krucho, bo takowe znajdujemy luzem, jak i zostaje nam po potworach. Jest też broń czy przedmioty dedykowane dla danej klasy. Taki minotaur zbiera czaszki, które podnoszą jego wartość ataku. Część fantów jest dobrze ukryta, bo twórcy umieścili w grze sporo sekretów, jak choćby zestawy unikalnych zbroi i potężnych broni. Niektóre z zagadek stanowią prawdziwe wyzwanie na szarych komórek.

Zagadki i pułapki są zresztą na porządku dziennym, dlatego warto uważać przy przeszukiwaniu ścian w nadziei znalezienia jakiegoś przycisku, otwierającego przejście do cennego przedmiotu. Czasami możemy natknąć się na jakieś napisy w formie zagadek, często bawiących się znaczeniem słów. Pierwszy lepszy przykład z rzędu. Napotykamy drzwi, obok których jest kamienna twarz i napis głoszący, że trzeba być cierpliwym. Wystarczy poczekać 15 sekund i voila. Drzwi się otworzą. Im dalej tym będzie oczywiście bardziej skomplikowanie, bo dojdą zapadnie i teleporty. Czasami na danym poziomie jesteśmy w stanie znaleźć niebieski kryształ. Poza zapisem gry, oferuje nam uzdrowienie. Jest też inny sposób na regenerację. Drużyna musi odpocząć poprzez sen, ale jeżeli nie oczyszczaliśmy korytarzy to możemy paść ofiarą ataku.

Potwory. Tutejszy troll z miejsca dołączył do moich ulubionych kreatur ever. Jest w dość późnej fazie gry, ale warto poczekać. Napotkamy też olbrzymie ślimaki, szkielety, ifryty ognia i wiele więcej. Zaskoczył mnie zaś końcowy boss. Oraz sposób w jaki z nim się rozprawiamy. Dobrze, że twórcy gry pokusili się o coś tak niestandardowego.

Gdyby zabrakło nam wrażeń to postacie zawsze można importować i rozpocząć grę na wyższym poziomie trudności, w dodatku włączając tryb w którym nie widać podręcznej mapy. To ukłoń w stronę starych wyjadaczy, kiedy to trzeba było sobie samemu rozrysować układ pomieszczeń na planszy. Taki smaczek z przeszłości dla hardcora. Fajnie.

Reasumując, nie mogło być inaczej. Gra ma swoje błędy, ale wiecie jak to jest z miłością. Jest ślepa. 10/10*

* gdybym jednak miał się kierować rozumem to dałbym pewnie z 8+ lub 9, bo gra nie ma większych wad.
 
Shadowdancer
708 produits enregistrés

Feels good.

Legend of Grimrock.... is not that...

..however it is a really good modern reboot of a kind of RPG that once did.

Its good.
 
LoKi³
0
4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
25.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 26 mai 2016
Legend of Grimrock is an excellent, atmospheric, well-made RPG in the style of much, MUCH older gems of the early 90's. The square-based movement style, and D&D style stats and gearing up, as well as the different patterns and intricacies of every enemy makes every encounter challenging, but not overpowering.

Legend of Grimrock has incredible atmosphere. In the tight, packed corridors, you feel constantly trapped in a labarinth of passages, doors and levers. With over seventy secrets, treasures and notes, Grimrock's focus on exploration never dilutes the main path, meaning that you can explore each area as much or as little as you want.

Legend of Grimrock's puzzles are very well made. Some require pinpoint reflexes and timing, while some require a more calculated and steady approach, but none feel impossible save one or two truly evil puzzles. The difficulty setting, however, is a tad arbitrary. Difficulty affects enemy stats and your hunger bar, but aside from that it changes nothing. Playing the game on easy will give you a much more enjoyable experience, and will not mean that a death of a party member is permanent.

That being said, I only experienced one game-over screen and that was due to my own misstep on the final boss (who is definately innovative, if a tad underwhelming).

This game is an excellent purchase, and a guaranteed source of enjoyment for a good ten or so hours, provided you do a full playthrough, fifteen if you're unfamilliar with the genre. The exploration bonus character makes for another interesting experience, so it may be wise to play through the game twice over - perhaps using a guide to help on the second time around.

In conclusion, Legend of Grimrock is a bonafide gem of a game, and I would reccomend this to any fan of RPG's
 
Enkazadas the Cosmic Traveller

8/10

These games are so cheap and offer many hours of playtime. That's not even including the workshop content which will extend it greatly.

Anyone familiar with older- mostly PC- RPGs like Eye Of the Beholder, Ravenloft: Stone Project, other D&D games like Warriors of the Eternal Sun, or allegedly like Dungeon Master (although I only played a little of DM2) will feel right at home with this.

If you like searching for hidden buttons, solving puzzles involving pressure pads, portals, pits, and wall nooks and clicking furiously to kill things with a quadrupedal party- this is a game for you.
 
jeikabu
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
22.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 19 juin 2015
A Paladin’s Review: Legend of Grimrock: Fun Old School Dungeon Crawling With A Creepy Atmosphere
  • Genre: 1st Person Old School Dungeon Crawling RPG.
  • Developed and Published by: Almost Human Games
  • Platform: Windows, MacOSX and Linux
  • Business Model: Base Game.
  • Copy Purchased by Myself
Read the full & unabridged review on A Paladin Without A Crusade[kingisaaclinksr.com]

Overall Gameplay Thoughts
Legend of Grimrock (LoG) is a RPG dungeon crawling adventure. It mixes old-school dungeon crawling with modern graphics and design. It focuses on survival and puzzle solving with some combat. Combat and travel is executed on a grid-based system. You and the enemies move forwards, backwards and sides in squares, an old-school throwback.

The Story
The game takes place in a world known only as The Northern Realms. You play as a group of four prisoners of varying races. These four prisoners have been sentenced for their crimes against the King by "The Court". Your sentence is to be thrown into the pit at the top of Mount Grimrock and once at the bottom of the pit, you'll be pardoned of your crimes. The only problem is, no one has survived the depths of Mount Grimrock. Can you survive past the creatures, traps and challenges before you? Well, your going to find out soon enough. Your mission is to do just that. You have to find out a way out of the place. Solve the puzzles, unlock the mysteries of Grimrock and survive. You're also being talked to in your dreams by someone...or something. The story is mostly told in dream sequences and scrolls left lying around in the dungeons. From these scrolls, you'll get clues to what's going on in the depths of Mount Grimrock as well as vague hints about the outside world.

Combat and Puzzles
LoG features combat, puzzle & riddle solving, RPG elements and exploration. Combat is tile based and in real time. Since it has this tile movement, your enemies must be directly facing you to attack. They're unable to attack at a diagonal from you. The combat system is a bit quirky and wonky. It takes quite a bit of practice to get used to fighting on what is essentially squares and being able to only face four directions. Not only that, it's in real-time, so creatures may come out of no where and take you by surprise. For the most part, the combat doesn't have a lot of depth but it's surprisingly enjoyable. Since you can't take too many direct hits from enemies, as they hit like a truck, most of the time will be spent sidestepping around enemies and poking them to death with spells and weapon swipes. This also means that getting caught in a surrounded by creatures will lead to a quick death. This can be a frustrating part of the game and it can happen almost too many times for comfort. However, it usually felt like I had gotten myself in that bad situation, not the game. So, you need to be very self-aware of your surroundings and survive as best you can. Fortunately, there's a finite amount of creatures on every level. Once you kill them all, you're given free reign to walk around and explore the level on your own terms. Still, I will say that the combat system stands on a razor's edge. At times it can be far too easy and others it can be far too frustrating. This is the type of system that if it strays just a little, will cease to be enjoyable.

There's also has a variety of different puzzles and riddles you must solve to not only advance but to find hidden secrets. Switches, levers, camouflaged buttons, defeating the right enemies or finding keys are all items used to impede your forward progress. Still, figuring it out is what I enjoy most about LoG. Even if it is tempting to use the Internet or Steam guides to solve a particularly tricky puzzle. (Which I did do that a couple of times. I know, I know). LoG definitely shines when it's about puzzles and less so when you're in combat. So, if you aren't a fan of puzzles, then you might not enjoy LoG that much.

Visuals
This game is a looker. Everything has a fidelity and crispness that you wouldn't expect out of such an indie project. The creature designs and animations are very well done. It was impressive how lifelike some of the attacking creatures looked when they attacked. Even if a lot of the animations are reused, I still think of these creatures being real, of having substance. The lighting system in this game is excellent, with shadows playing lifelike over the walls and creatures as you move about. It all sells the experience of being in a dark, underground dungeon.

Audio and Atmosphere
While LoG has an awesome intro menu song that pumps you up for action, there isn't any music in the game itself. Instead, the game has whistling, quiet winds and other sound elements that sell the atmosphere of LoG. This sense that you're in an underground dungeon that is out to kill you. That every step forward is both a step towards ultimate freedom and possible death. Just to really sink it in, they let you hear the footsteps of potential enemies nearby. As though at any time, they might pop out of the wall and split you in two. But you wanna know the best part? There are some enemies that stand perfectly still until it's much too late. Think on that for a while.

PC Settings and More
LoG comes with all the graphics, audio and keybinding settings you'll need. Resolution options are plentiful and it can display in fullscreen, windowed borderless and windowed. V-sync has a enabled/disabled setting. Texture resolution, filtering, shadow quality and SSAO quality have low-medium-high sliders. There's also separate audio sliders with mute options. Autosave can be turned on/off with other minor settings included as well. Keyboard controls can be completely configured if needed. You can also enable a touchscreen/tablet mode which is pretty neat. There is no FOV slider and this is probably intentional for game balance. I can't say for certain if the FoV is fine or not but I think the grid-based movement will prevent any motion sickness from becoming an issue. It should be noted that Steam cloud isn't enabled for LoG.

Final Thoughts
I really enjoyed exploring through the depths of Mount Grimrock. The creepy atmosphere is ever present as you crawl through empty halls expecting danger to popout at any second. The combat is pretty good as well but it can easily tip towards too easy or too frustrating. Legend of Grimrock was an unexpected treat and pleasure for me to play through. It isn't often that I find a game that just clicks with me like this one did. While a few of the puzzles were a bit of a hair-pullers, some of the riddles moreso, I didn't feel like they were too opaque or difficult to figure out. Though it's really tempting to just use the internet or Steam guides to get all the answers. Even so, there's 20 hours of content to enjoy. Side note: Legend of Grimrock was one of my favorite games of 2012.

Read the full, unabridged review on A Paladin Without A Crusade[kingisaaclinksr.com]
A Paladin’s Review: Legend of Grimrock 2. The Island of Broken Bones and Death Traps
Read the notes on this updated review[wp.me]
 
Tim Starstriker
1,209 produits enregistrés
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
10.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 18 avril 2012
Whoa! Nostalgia! What we have here is a 2012 blend of the old classics, Stonekeep, Eye of The Beholder and of course, the legendary Dungeon Master by FTL.

It's a 3D viewable game, played in the step-forward, back, left and right mentality. The story? Your 4-man party has been thrown into a prison-style keep called Grimrock.

Can you survive?

Yes - that's it.

Surely that's a problem?

No. Not at all.

In the current climate of RPG genres where back-stories, multi-layer character development and seemingly endless dialogue all vie for supremacy, LoG is wonderfully absent of all this 'clutter'. You're in a hole - get on with it.

Newcomers to RPGs may instantly be put off by its appearance - but that's only skin-deep. Veterans of the Amiga/Atari ST days will immediately feel at home with this and end up just spending '10 minutes more' on it. Simple, honest, fun. A brilliant first-step for those people who might think RPGs are usually quite daunting.

Certainly recommended. 8.5
 
Unzen
1,045 produits enregistrés
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
31.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 11 juin 2012
Bottom line: Grimrock is a dungeon crawl modelled after the one and only Eye of the Beholder. Eye of the Beholder was the first of it's type... a trend-setter that broke every rule for a game of it's type efore it. Of course, its only a step away from the RPG we enjoy now with 360 degree view of the game world. BUT, in that light it is a nice fresh return to that style of rpg.

Yes, its difficult. Yes, its quirky. I simply argue that it's the quirks that make it unique... and at $10 its a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ deal.
 
Mork d'Ork
0
4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé

Great game.

Reminds me a lot of the eye of the beholder series with better graphics, cleaner UI, real time combat, and simpler mazes. (the maze puzzles in EOB were a bit over the top requiring a degree in dungeon mapping and a cheat guide though so this is a good thing)

Played through it twice just for fun with a second set of characters.

1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
31.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 26 novembre 2017
Playing this on a 3.3 GHz iMac, with the AMD Radeon R9 M395, El Capitan 10.11.6.

This game promises to recreate the great dungeon crawler games of the past, Dungeon Master & Eye of the Beholder, and it does so brilliantly. It takes all the elements that made those games so much fun, and gives them a nice little polish for today’s gamer.

The graphics may not seem cutting edge to a lot of modern players, but they perfectly recreate those classic games, as does the sound, game play & UI.

I have not had run across any glitches or bugs playing on my Mac, which is not always the case with PC games that are usually programed for Windows first, and ported to the Mac as an afterthought.

There have been only two parts of the game that have dampened my enthusiasm for playing it. The first is that some of the puzzles make no logical sense. I have had to resort to game guides at a couple of spots that I could not figure out, and when I read the solution I was like “You have to be kidding me!” It was something like, spin around three times, click your heels together while saying “There’s no place like home”, while poking yourself in the eye with a vorpal blade, and finishing by throwing yourself down a pit of death. Maybe not quite that absurd, but I would doubt that anyone will figure out every puzzle without resorting to a game guide.

And there are a couple of spots that even when I knew what I had to do after reading said game guide, it was crazy hard to actually complete the puzzle. I am currently stuck in a room filled with fiery Uggardians and pits in which I have been unable to get past.

Don’t tell me I need to “Git Gud”. At my age, I’m as “Gud” as I’m ever going to “Git”!

Still, I would highly recommend this game. It satisfies the nostalgia urge in anyone who ever played Eye of the Beholder on their old Amiga or Atari ST. (both of which I owned.)
 
kycaver
1,050 produits enregistrés
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
7.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 14 mars 2016
Legend of Grimrock

My first Dungeon Crawler I've ever played and I have to admit it makes much more fun as I've thought while I saw a little part of a Let's Play.
GamePlay:
The Game is in 3D but you can only move ion tiles and turn 90° around. (except for the free mouse view)
Move: w,a,s,d as you know it from the most games.
q,e for turning 90° left or right.
Your party is made out of 4 individual made Characters.
2 Front Row - advantage: Melee attacks reach the enemies; disadvantage: Take the hits of front attacks.
2 Back Row - advantage: Save for front attacks, may get hits from back or side attacks; disadvantage: cannot reach the enemy with melee weapons. (Of course there are some exceptions)
You can choose between different breeds which have their own benefits and these players can be signed as: Mage, Warrior, Rogue - to gain skills of their speciality.
★ ★ ★ ★ ★

Graphics:
Looks in my opinion fairly nice. No complain!
★ ★ ★ ★ ★

Story:
hmmm... Not really an impressive story. Get thrown into a Mountain and you have to escape...
The helping "thing" in the dreams and all the notes of toorum makes it a bit more interesting.
★ ★ ★ ☆ ☆

Leveldesign:
It is impressive to see that they got 71 secrets on 13 different Levels. I didn't get even 50 at my first playthrough. As I said, Impressive work. Nice riddles...
★ ★ ★ ★ ★

Music:
Well... the theme Music at the Menu is amazing. <3 But the whole game has no other soundtrack, at least no soundtrack I've heard... Not even the Boss has one and that was a bit disappointing. Still 4 Stars for that amazing Menu Music!
★ ★ ★ ★ ☆

All in one it was a bunch of fun I had with this Game, even it was sometimes pretty unfair. :<
Well... Doesn't matter. This deserven a ★ ★ ★ ★ ★ rating from me. Well done!
 
OregoX

Non recommandé
19.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 10 mai 2014
Yes, I know, it's a whiny statement, but let me kind of explain why I feel this way and perhaps it'll make more sense.

I get the dungeon crawl concept. I've played them before, and roguelikes. Against all expectations, I beat the hardest of hardcore modes on Dungeons of Dredmor, I went through a couple playthroughs of Dark Souls, all that stuff. When I lose in those games, I feel it's because I did something to mess up, missed a move or made a wrong decision.

With this game, there is no wrong decision to make, because no matter what you decide, you get thrown up against a difficulty spike that you can't possibly be ready for until you die at least once to it. If it isn't the obtuse puzzles that only make sense about half the time, it's the enemies that pop out of nowhere, can take forty times as many hits as any of your characters, and deal out damage that can kill you in seconds in a straight fight.

I know a lot of people may disagree with this, and they certainly have a right to. But to me, this game isn't a challenge, or a dungeon crawl. It's just mashing my face against random walls in the hopes of finding a hidden switch, and getting killed a dozen times by the same overpowered monster group until I find the hidden cheese tactic that somehow lets me go down another floor.
 
Miketopus
2,538 produits enregistrés
1
4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
87.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 3 janvier 2021
An amazing game, a reminder of my days playing Eye Of The Beholder on Amiga nearly 30 years ago. This is a great dungeon crawler with a varied bestiary and lots of secret areas, spells, weapons etc for your party of 4 characters to explore. Without doubt it's a tough game but there are locations on most levels where you are able to replenish health and energy and resurrect fallen characters. There is some backtracking through the game mainly due to food supplies and finding treasures or secrets but on the whole it's hugely enjoyable and the dungeon crawling experience is rejuvenated thanks to this gem.
 
Diamondback66
0
4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
6.0 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 8 janvier 2013
Concept: a band of four prisoners is taken to the dungeon of Grimrock for their crimes, where none thus far have ever escaped.

Gameplay: despite its appearance, it is NOT turn-based. It's realtime, although most enemies' movements have LONG delays. You navigate on a strict grid and cannot cut diagonals. The combat consists of clicking weapons and hoping for special attacks, or clicking magic and casting your own damn spell. Not that the rune system really helps you.

Graphics: look closely and you'll notice that the texture on the face of every wall is exactly the same. The graphics, even aside from the walls, are pretty lazy, although the monsters are fine. However, the headbobbing of moving around is a wonderful way to get sick.

Audio: no music. Just generic, boring ambience and a single audio effect for each monster that you get to hear 20 times a minute.

Difficulty: dungeon crawler. It has difficulty settings, although I have only played one difficulty thus far, so I've no idea what the difficulty affects.

Synopsis: hardly worth $15(but I got it cheaper) unless you're really into dungeon crawlers.
 
alphappy
336 produits enregistrés
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile

Recommandé
17.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 20 décembre 2014
LoG est un dungeon-crawler, un genre de jeu qu'il a lui-même ressuscité, rien que ça !

Les vieux de la vieille saurons de quoi il est question et s’empresseront de l'acheter tant celui-ci est réussi. Les néophytes aurons peut être plus de mal à s'y mettre, mais si vous vous intéressez au jeu, n’hésitez plus et franchissez le pas. C'est le premier dungeon crawler que j'ai finit et je ne le regrette absolument pas.

Legend of Grimrock est très long, il ne brille pas par son scenario ni par la diversité de ses environnements mais par la diversité de son bestiaire et par l'inventivité de ses énigmes.

Le seul reproche que j'aurais à faire au jeu est qu'il est plutôt difficile de terminer le jeu sans récupérer les objets cachés dans des zones secrètes, et que ça rend l'utilisation d'un guide parfois obligatoire.

Я просто в восторге что ребята из Almost Human вернулись к классике и сделали просто велеколепную игру! Запутанные лабиринты, трудно убиваеммые супостаты, множесто секретов (которые действиетельно Секреты - найти порой практически невозможно), мозговыносящие загадки и испытания, отличная картинка и физика, неплохой сюжет (хоть его там и совсем чуть-чуть) заставляют погружатся в игру и забывать о времени! А обещенный редактор подземелий, который разработчики выпустят чуть позже, должен дать игре долгую жизнь!

36.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 6 janvier 2014
Classic dungeon crawler in modern wrapping, extremely fun to play and explore. Stats and achievements add value by showing if you discovered all the secrets and found all treasures. Can it get any better? Well it can, and it did - by adding a dungeon editor, which allowed the community to recreate timeless classics like Dungeon Master using LoG engine!

Granted, it's not perfect - pretty shallow story and quite a limited bestiary, but it's still a great little gem, especially if you take in account that the production team consisted of just four people. Well done!

Non recommandé
39.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 9 octobre 2023
I loved Eye of the Beholder, my first experience of the first person, party-style dungeon crawler that practically invented the phrase 'Item conservation'.

I enjoyed this game a lot too, but as a completionist, it got painful. Some of the puzzles are extremely challenging to solve without a guide, and if you miss or lose a single scroll, they can be impossible without being told what to do. The 'Doin it Old School' achievement was PAINFUL. It's a hard-coded dungeon, there's not much replayability. It basically just asked us to play a second time but twice as tediously. I'm not saying it's bad. I'm saying this nostalgic throwback shows the formats age. If you like this kind of game, you probably need about 20 hours to 100%. My hours are longer because I sucked and really tried to self-solve some puzzles.

Évaluation publiée le 3 février 2014
Being a big fan of various dungeon crawlers in the olden days I can honestly recommend this game to any gamer who loved Eye of the Beholder, Dungeon Master, Stonekeep and many other games like that in the 1990s. Legend of Grimrock brings the same feeling and atmosphere with modern looks and technology, and there is a huge modding community with large number of custom dungeons for those who long for more after finishing the main quest. Swords in your hands and onwards we go!

2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile

Recommandé
101.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 2 mars 2014
Prepare to die, again and again. 'Legend of Grimrock' is a hardcore RPG even in normal difficulty. Either I made all the wrong choices either your party is always at a (more than slight) disadvantage as you get to higher levels. I've been poisoned and eaten alive by spiders, incinerated by those flying armored mages, and even chewed up by frosty lizards. The devs really want you to suffer in this dungeon that often seems like a dead end as it's almost impossible to fight and defeat more than one enemy at the time. All the fighting is done real time but there are no shortcuts or hotkeys, therefore the computer will always be quicker then you as you will struggle to command the attack with your mouse - especially with the spells that need several inputs : choosing the wand, choosing 1-4 runes, and then pressing on the attack button AGAIN! But most of all the puzzles will drive you crazy: 'The Maze of Madness' will drive you as mad as hell until you can't take it anymore (or find the improbable solution with no hints whatsoever) and the mostly random logic will leave your characters and yourself starving while you bang your head against the wall.

The minimalistic nature of the game is classy, but the lack of real meaning to many of the puzzles is frustrating; some are genuinely good and easy to understand thanks to a scroll (the shadow maze for instance), but now I'm currently stuck in an endless hall in level 9. There's probably a hint I'm missing somewhere in the slaughterfest but maybe I'll die before I find it. I might never see the light of day, after all I've been there for over 24h already...Grimrock don't roll, it's a total headbanger!

PS: I eventually found the scroll and got to the game's over-the-top goofy conclusion; you have to see it to believe it! Also the level editor is great and relatively easy to use and some of the mods are actuallly way more enjoyable than the original, there's this awesome Mine of Malan Vael and The Tower of Bones that could both easily be official DLCs while we are all waiting for the sequel.
 
Alleycat
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0

Have never played this kind of game before so can't tell how it compares to old school 3D dungeon crawlers, all I know is that I enjoyed pretty much every bit of it. Combat is fun and puzzles are often clever and challenging. There might have been couple times where i had to search for some solutions but it was mostly due to misunderstanding from my end. There are loads of secrets, traps and different items throughout the game.

You can tell Almost Human Games were very passionate about this project.

Time for Legend of Grimrock 2 now.

I heartily recommend this game to every nostalgic soul out there.

This game successfully combines old dungeon crawler genre with some new elements, and by doing that, it feels refreshing and nostalgic, at the same time. :)

The graphics, sounds and overall atmosphere in this game are great, however there are a few things that bother me. Too many puzzles, and a sudden change in difficulty after level 3, do raise an eyebrow or two...but like I said, it's still a great game.

Recommandé
8.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 27 novembre 2012
Fun, old-school dungeon crawl in the style of Eye of the Beholder. Despite the fact that it gives you options to play on 'Normal' or 'Hard', I'm finding that 'Normal' is quite challenging enough!

For difficult encounters, I suggest kiting. In LoG, that means running away while throwing stuff (including spells). Torches can be thrown if you run out of more pointy things.

Rest often. Food seems to be pretty plentiful, and it seems that actions (like fighting and exploring) make you more hungry than resting.
 
Teellox
377 produits enregistrés
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
1
Recommandé
32.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 25 avril 2012
What a fun little game this is! It is a very lightweight game which offers a surprising amount of dungeon crawling enjoyment! I think it's beauty lies in it's simplicity - it's basically just a 2D grid environment with 3D perspective graphics. Your party of 4 adventurers take up one tile and can only move one tile at a time either north, south, east or west. Combat is basically hack n slash but there is quite a bit of timing involved and strategy with how you use your 2 'front row' characters who can melee directly as opposed to the 2 'back row' characters who can either use ranged attacks/magic or perks to do melee attacks from afar. But sometimes you might find yourself cornered where monsters surround you and take big bites out of your typically soft back row guys.

There are alot of interesting puzzles some of which can drive you mad trying to figure them out! I really also like how food plays into the game (your guys need to eat!) and how items are very scarce.
 
TheDarkside

Agoraphobic
0
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
13.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 17 avril 2012
Awesome game! A throwback to old tile-based dungeon crawler games, this game is real-time, difficult, and bleak.

You control a whole party of 4 adventurers that are forced by their ankle chains to stand on the same square. There are tons of puzzles as well as tough monster fights. Secret rooms everywhere! Your characters need to eat occasionally or they start to recieve negative effects, forcing you to keep moving deeper towards your own doom.

Everything seems well balanced, though it is balanced towards difficulty. In order to do well in combat, you are expected to perform a ballet dance, attacking the enemies from the side and sidestepping them before they turn to face you. You will probably end up dying a lot, so save often. If you want a real challenge, there is an option to turn off the map, forcing you to use graph paper to map out the dungeon as you go.

The game is said to last at least 10 hours, and a level editor and mod support are coming soon.
 
Rebecca Labfiend
0

42.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 30 novembre 2014
The game started off being very entertaining, but it became less and less of an RPG and more of a "twitch" reflex game. I had to quit at level 6 where you are required to press three different buttons in sequence with absolutely no room for thought or planning. If you enjoy very fast complicated key strokes with split second timing, this may appeal to you. If you want a real RPG, look else where.
 
frua97
0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
15.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 2 juillet 2016
I wasn't really sure if this type of game would really be something I'd enjoy, but now that I've completed my first playthrough I can say I thoroughly enjoyed the experience. The combat is well designed and varied, and it is simple enough for anyone to pick up, but there's still a surprising amount of depth to it as well. The puzzles were also very well done, never feeling illogical or unfair. However, they were still challenging enough that completing them always felt rewarding.

Overall, Legend of Grimrock is a great game that takes an old formula not really seen in video games these days, and creates something unique from it.
 
Darashiva
0
8 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
15.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 9 décembre 2015
ナメクジとキノコのバターいため

スクリーンショットを見て、ピンときた人もいるかもしれないが
このゲームはダンジョンマスター[ja.wikipedia.org]をリスペクトした
ダンジョン探索型RPGである

マス目移動式だが、全てがリアルタイムに進行するので
常に周りに気を配らなければあっという間に
ダンジョン内の魔物や危険な罠によってPTメンツが
骨にされてしまうだろう
迷宮特有の謎解きもあり、床や壁をしっかり見ておかないと
前の階に戻るハメに…という事も

冒険者は生き物なのでもちろんおなかが減ります
しかし迷宮内では贅沢など言ってられない
空腹になると体力が自然回復しなくなるので
ナメクジの肉やらネズミの肉やら昆虫やらキノコやらなどを
ある程度確保しておかねばならない

戦闘システムはハクスラ式であり、職業によって
割り振れるスキルが違う
満遍なくやるよりは、一つを徹底的にあげた方が
戦闘が楽になるかもしれないが
キャラのポートレイトを好きに変更する事が出来るので
「このキャラはこういうスキルかな…」とあえて満遍なく振るのもイイかも

謎解き難易度は調べないと無理だろこれ！というのもあるが
まず最初は調べないでこの迷宮に潜る事を奨める
 
ヤニュウ
0
5 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
1.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 1 janvier 2014
Prepare to click. A lot. This game decides that the ideal way to make a game difficult and "old school" is to make the controls awful. There are no useful keyboard shortcuts for anything, and it employs realtime combat with you controlling all four party members. Making a game's controls awful to increase difficulty doesn't make it fun, just frustrating.

Click to attack, click to move, click to turn, click to cast a spell, click to open your inventory, it gets old very fast. I couldn't even stomach a second hour of play, and I normally love games with old school themes or mechanics. I honestly think it got such good reviews because the genre is starved for this sort of old dungeon crawl, rather than another Minecraft-like. But they could have done much, much better.
 
Nomad Time Lord

This is a strong reminder of that game.. I had many good memories of it.. and i shall intent to create many fond memories of this one too.

2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile

Recommandé
33.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 25 novembre 2017
A very nice indie dungeon crawler.

The good:
+ Puzzles are awesome
+ Beautiful monster animations
+ Sound effects are nice. Hitting a monster with a fireball or a weapon makes a gratifying sound

The bad:
- A bit tedious at times. Killing monsters at normal difficulty can feel like a grind instead of being challenging
- The story isn't very involving. In other words, writing could be better
- Levels are a bit bland, they don't give you any "Woah!"-experiences. I mean maps could be built so that they tell a story of something that happened there before.
- I dislike the final boss. It's just not very cool. Unforgettable maybe, but not cool.

Overall, I don't regret completing the game.
 
Turbopause

Évaluation publiée le 16 juillet 2020
LoG is a very good old school dungeon crawler, similar to classics like Eye of Beholder. All the mechanics are quite simple and easy to master. It is fun to explore all the levels and discover secrets and hidden treasures. Most of them are rewarding. But it would be better if there is a larger variety of switches and ways to discover hidden areas. Maybe breaking walls or illusion walls.

The puzzles and the atmosphere are pretty good but the combat is just: hit with all your guys, try to run away from the enemy if you can, then go again. sometimes you have the space to dance around the monster and avoid hits or you can stand behind a door and just open it when your party can attack. thats just flat out boring. But i haven't told you how you heal... by resting, you just stand around and do nothing a bunch. its like a cover shooter with hp regen where you just hide, shot a bunch, repeat.

1,877 produits enregistrés

1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation utile

Recommandé
1,668.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 2 juillet 2019
My first dungeon crawler was Eye Of The Beholder I on 3.5 inch floppy disk.

We've come a long way.

Since that time, I have always loved dungeon crawlers, my favorite probably being Might & Magic VI. So when I was told about Legend Of Grimrock, I was cautiously optimistic. I was hoping for the best but expecting the worst.

I was not disappointed.

As good as the main game is, it's the mods that really shine, my favorites being One Room Round Robin 2, Bloodwych and the mod of the original dungeon. All 3 are beyond incredible.

You can see how many hours I have in this game. Some of the mods I have played numerous times.

If you're a fan of the old time dungeon crawlers, don't even think about it. Just get this game. I promise you, you won't be disappointed.

Lots of fun if you don't mind the movement system and sometimes awkward combat, graphics are nice, there's a good amount of customization and lots of different items you can find, hidden secrets, clever puzzles, decent variety of enemies and an interesting sort of backstory-thing involving notes and dreams, LoG has a lot of good stuff in it, if you like dungeon crawling-type games you'll probably love this. Also you can create your own dungeons or play other people's which can be surprsingly good, adding to replayability

Recommandé
30.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 21 octobre 2016
I usually don't like playing dungeon crawler games but this was different. This game is a great deal of fun and with a interesting twist of playing as four charaters, or one if you so choose. (It's REALLY hard though.) I really like how I never felt forced to have rogue or a mage in my party. Sure it's easier with a least one mage and very hard with no warriors, but you can still play it as you want. You're never locked out of a area if you don't have a rogue to unlock the way. As for the story its a little sparse compared to games like Dragon Age or Mass Effect, but there is enough of a story to get behind and a mystery to further pull you along. You up your own idea's to it if your the imaginive type.

The Puzzles are a bit hard especially if you are running this on weak computer. (some of the puzzles are timed) Even so I would Highly recommend this game!

19.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 9 novembre 2015
I never was much for games that require parties. To be honest, I didn't even like the Dragon Age series. However, this game is the exception to the rule. There's just something charmin and magical about the way this game works, as you and your merry team of four carefully collect the scarce resources around you and master difficult puzzles.

Pros:
+Old-school charm
+Good puzzles
+Calm, but engaging combat
+Good creature and level design

Neutral:
Story is a bit subtle.

♥♥♥♥:
-Old-school difficulty
-Sometimes you need a walkthrough

Overall, I strongly recommend this game. It's a blast to play, and a good way to simultaneously unwind and put your brain to good use, too.

0
Recommandé
289.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 24 février 2019
Fave Dungeon Crawler: Legend of Grimrock aka LOG aka Grimmy

This is by far my favourite dungeon crawler. It has, well, a dungeon, monsters to fight, magic spells to cast, treasures to find, secrets to unlock, tricky but solvable puzzles, with the usuals of course!

With a 4 character party, all controlled and customised by you. These individual characters have their own lore, skills, weapons and armour that can be levelled up and changed throughout the game but choose wisely.

Originally accessing this game on a Mac platform and then bringing it over to Windows Steam platform, it is one of those rare games that once complete I can keep coming back to play it through, again and again, with a different approach and characters. Great way to relax and wind down from the day!

Well, I best get back to it so I can get me those Steam badges.

furydante
1,053 produits enregistrés
0
2 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
23.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 30 mai 2021
Legend of Grimrock makes me nostalgic for games I haven't played. Five minutes with this title tells you its harkening back to an older era, with its obtuse controls and unforgiving nature, but the clarity of the game's central mechanics makes for an ultimately inviting experience. Games have long since moved past the limitations found here, yet I find it fascinating how making a modern game under these same rules shows just how effectively these design choices work, even now. I’ve never played anything quite like Grimrock, and I think that's why I enjoyed it as much as I did.

Innovation
What immediately stands about Grimrock is its grid based nature. Everything in this game, from movement, item placement and dungeon layout, is mapped to a square grid. It’s almost reminiscent of a real-time D&D game, and it can be pretty hard to get used to, but I appreciate the amount of time given to the player to adapt to these controls in the early stages.

And once you’ve adapted to the controls, my god they’re interesting. Grimrock’s limitations compliment every aspect of the gameplay, your movement in combat and puzzles feels like such an important aspect to consider at all times, and it makes the game far more readable. The reigned in scope provides such familiarity as you know your toolkit perfectly as you face every hazard.

I also think this grid system works brilliantly for exploration. With such a limited budget, the grid based system makes environments much easier to keep track of due to their predictable rigidness. And yet, environments manage to consistently surprise, with each floor feeling fondly unique from one another as you slowly unveil more of this mysterious dungeon.

I highly recommend playing on old-school mode, which requires you to manually draw your own maps. There’s an added level of challenge having to rely on your own inconsistent mind to keep track of where you’ve been, and I found taking notes alongside the map on paper greatly deepened the experience.

I’m used to seeing dungeons at a hallmark in many adventures, but the atmosphere Grimrock provides by encapsulating its entire run within one dungeon is so brilliant and unique. The constant dark corridors and mysterious echoes create a great state of unease, making those moments where you find a life crystal so much more rewarding as a beacon of safety. Even in those moments, Grimrock masterfully delivers on that foreboding sense, as you’re never truly separated from the rest of the horrors one might find in the dungeon.

Gameplay
Grimrock main gameplay loop is a combination of combat and exploration, but you’re rarely doing one without the other. Understanding your environments in battles is essential due to the importance of movement in combat, and makes for a great sense of flow as you have to manage both foes and the space around you. While I think the quantity of things you could do in combat was severely hampered by the lack of playable classes, the core loop of environmental management made in a restrictive landscape made for a satisfyingly innovative combat system.

I deeply appreciated how manual everything was too. Each of your party needs to be managed separately, which can be quite chaotic in harder encounters, but I think it fleshes out their appeal for potential strategies. Melee characters will have different cooldown times to account for with positioning, and memorising spells is an arduous process that makes it all the more satisfying when you finally get into a good rhythm. I think it's just another reason why old-school mode works so well with Grimrock, the game celebrates the player input as much as possible, and lets its simplistic mechanics cultivate a unique experience for every player.

The “upgrade” system felt quite special too. Regardless of your class choices, each member of your party starts with no equipment, which really emphasizes the progression you feel as you slowly power up your team. Even a regular sword feels like a huge find after bashing your way through the game, I don’t think I’ve ever had so much joy for acquiring a basic item. You spend so much of this game slowly equipping yourself for a battle, that the rush felt when finally building a mighty team really hits home on the satisfaction feel, the power climb feels so distinct throughout the game when you remember your harsh beginnings.

Combat could feel occasionally strained however, with the bigger encounters. There are plenty of enemy types whose shocking unpredictability tested my limits, but every now and then you’re merely thrown to a room with high health enemies, forced to repeat the same basic strategies to slowly chip their health away. I greatly appreciated the moments in Grimrock that tested my strategic capabilities, which were certainly plentiful and exhilarating, but these grindy moments were unfortunately just a little bit too common.

Environments
The dungeon levels itself have quite a well thought out layout. Careful considerations have been placed into every area, I like how each floor tends to have either a theme or mechanic to keep them a remarkable point of the game. There's an amazing amount of diversity in environmental design that always keeps you on your toes, the tightly knit corridors of the earlier floors limit movement, making enemy arrivals terrifying, yet the pitch black open areas keep you constantly in fear of what lies beyond your sight.

Unfortunately, the environmental design can only distract for so long from the repetitive aesthetic. The majority of Grimrock keeps you looking at the small selection of visual textures, with overhauls only appearing a couple times throughout the game. It can’t help but make the game look a bit dull at times, but it also has mechanic issues, as many secrets become a bit too easy to spot since the hidden button is always placed the same way on every wall. It would’ve been nice to have a bit more visual variety given how limited the layout the grid based layouts can be.

On a more positive note, the dedication to loading this game with secrets is insane. For such a title focused around linear progression, it's crazy how many secrets doors or riddles can lead to a variety of new equipment and encounters. I can’t imagine how many nooks and crannies I missed, but the amount I did find always left a great feeling when I conquered one of the game's challenges. The puzzles are pretty great in general, with the right amount of information conveyed to the player, yet leaving it open enough to be challenging. There were a couple required to progress at the end I thought were a bit too vague, but I liked how typically the biggest riddles were for optional loot, giving the player the decision of spending time and resources for the mystery of a great reward.

8/10
Legend of Grimrock is a really interesting game that feels like no other. I immensely enjoyed my time with this title, and think it's well worth checking out.
 
Wil Darlington
1,112 produits enregistrés
0

Recommandé
33.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 14 octobre 2017
Absolutely amazing game, with great puzzles and some difficult battles that reward your skills and smarts. The retro design is not for everyone, so watch some videos before commiting. But as far as RPG, combat, puzzles and inmersion go, what this game accomplish with such and old school structure is magnificent.

You can also try some mods to extend the experience, although I recommend going straight to LoG II. After that, sadly, we shall starve.

Recommandé
60.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 13 octobre 2022
Très bon Dungeon Crawler qui reprend les codes des vieux jeux comme Eye Of The Beholder, Dungeon Master, etc... mais le tout avec la technologie des années 2010.

C'est à dire combats en temps réels exigeants, immersion réussie et puzzles (pour ces derniers, heureusement il y a des soluces sur internet).

Je recommande !

( ) Crianças
( ) Tudo e todos
